{{refimprove|date=March 2010}} [[File:Chamberlain.jpg|thumb|[[Joseph Chamberlain]] sporting a monocle]]
A '''monocle''' is a type of [[corrective lens]] used to correct or enhance the [[visual perception|vision]] in only one [[Human eye|eye]]. It consists of a circular [[Lens (optics)|lens]], generally with a wire ring around the circumference that can be attached to a string or wire. The other end of the string is then connected to the wearer's clothing to avoid losing the monocle. The [[antiquarian]] [[Philipp von Stosch]] wore a monocle in Rome in the 1720s, in order to closely examine [[engraving]]s and antique [[engraved gem]]s, but the monocle did not become an article of gentlemen's apparel until the nineteenth century. It was introduced by the [[dandy]]'s '''quizzing glass''' of the 1790s, as a sense of high fashion.<ref>{{cite web|title=Monocles|url=http://www.college-optometrists.org/en/college/museyeum/online_exhibitions/spectacles/monocles.cfm|work=Spectacles Gallery|publisher=The College of Optometrists|accessdate=2014-03-19}}</ref>
==Styles== [[File:monocle with gallery.jpg|thumb|left|An early-20th-century [[gold-filled jewelry|gold-filled]] monocle with gallery]] There are three styles of monocle. The first style consists of a simple loop of metal with a lens which was slotted into the eye [[orbit (anatomy)|orbit]]. These were the first monocles worn in England and could be found from the 1830s onwards. The second style, which was developed in the 1890s, was the most elaborate, consisting of a frame with a raised edge-like extension known as the ''gallery''.<ref>Ekstein, J. and J. & G. Perkinks. ''Gentlemen's Dress Accessories''. Shire Publications. U.K.:1994. {{ISBN|0-85263-904-X}}</ref> The gallery was designed to help secure the monocle in place by raising it out of the eye's orbit slightly, so that the eyelashes would not jar it. Monocles with galleries were often the most expensive. The very wealthy would have the frames custom-made to fit their eye sockets. A sub-category of the galleried monocle was the "sprung gallery", where the gallery was replaced by an incomplete circle of flattened, ridged wire supported by three posts. The ends were pulled together, the monocle was placed in the eye orbit, and the ends released, causing the gallery to spring out and keep the monocle in place. The third style of monocle was frameless. This consisted of a cut piece of glass, with a serrated edge to provide a grip and sometimes a hole drilled into one side for a cord. Often the frameless monocle had no cord and would be worn freely. This style was popular at the beginning of the 20th century as the lens could be cut to fit any shape eye orbit inexpensively, without the cost of a customized frame.
It is a myth that wearing a monocle is uncomfortable{{Citation needed|date=February 2018}}. If customised, monocles could be worn securely with little effort. However, periodic adjustment is a fact of life for monocle wearers to keep the monocle from popping, as can be seen in films featuring [[Erich von Stroheim]]. Often only the rich could afford to have a monocle custom-fabricated, while the poor had to settle for ill-fitting monocles that were both less comfortable and less secure. The popular perception was (and still is) that a monocle could easily fall off with the wrong [[facial expression]]. This is true to an extent, as raising the eyebrow too far will allow the monocle to fall. [[File:Quizzingglass.jpg|thumb|right|19th-century [[Gold-filled jewelry|gold-filled]] quizzing glass]]A once-standard [[comedic device]] exploits this: an upper-class gentleman effects a shocked expression in response to some event, and his monocle falls into his drink, or smashes to pieces on the floor, etc. Another myth is that [[Abraham Lincoln]] wore a monocle. <ref>Ekstein, J. and J. & G. Perkinks. Gentlemen's Dress Accessories. Shire Publications. U.K.:1994. {{ISBN|0-85263-904-X}}</ref> It has also been said that he created his own style of monocle and wore it when he was away from the public or very rarely when in public.
The quizzing glass should not be confused with a monocle, since it is held to one's eye with a handle in a fashion similar to a [[lorgnette]]. A quizzing glass is not held by the eye socket itself.
==Wearers== During the late 19th and early 20th centuries, the monocle was generally associated with wealthy upper-class men.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.slate.com/articles/life/luxury_explainer/2012/12/monocles_how_did_they_become_a_symbol_of_wealth.html |title=The One-Eyed Man Is King |author= J. Bryan Lowder |date=December 27, 2012 |work=Slate |accessdate=2014-01-04}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.msnbc.com/rachel-maddow-show/monocles-ow-do-people-really-wear-these |title=Monocles: ‘Ow, do people really wear these?’ |author=Will Femia |date=September 19, 2012 |publisher=MSNBC |accessdate=2014-01-04}}</ref> Combined with a [[morning coat]] and a [[top hat]], the monocle completed the costume of the stereotypical 1890s [[Capitalism|capitalist]]. Monocles were also accessories of [[German Army (German Empire)|German military]] officers from this period; especially from [[World War I]] and [[World War II]]. German military officers known to have worn a monocle include [[Hans Krebs (Wehrmacht general)|Hans Krebs]], [[Werner von Fritsch]],<ref name="schikelgruber">{{cite web|url=http://schikelgruber.net/images/fritsch.jpg|title=Image: fritsch.jpg|publisher=schikelgruber.net|accessdate=2015-09-04|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120320111314/http://schikelgruber.net/images/fritsch.jpg|archive-date=2012-03-20|dead-url=yes|df=}}</ref> [[Erich Ludendorff]],<ref name="mousely">{{cite web|url=http://mousely.com/wiki_image/6/6a/VonLudendorff.jpg|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110727082022/http://mousely.com/wiki_image/6/6a/VonLudendorff.jpg|dead-url=yes|archive-date=2011-07-27|title=Image: VonLudendorff.jpg|publisher=mousely.com|accessdate=2015-09-04}}</ref> [[Walter Model]],<ref>http://home.scarlet.be/~tsc94696/images/Walter_Model.jpg{{dead link|date=February 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref> [[Walter von Reichenau]], [[Dietrich von Saucken]], [[Hans von Seeckt]],<ref name="preussen-chronik">{{cite web|url=http://www.preussen-chronik.de/bilder/1265_Hans_von_Seeckt.jpeg|title=Image: 1265_Hans_von_Seeckt.jpeg, (349 × 480 px)|publisher=preussen-chronik.de|accessdate=2015-09-04}}</ref> and [[Hugo Sperrle]].
Monocles were most prevalent in the late 19th century, but are rarely worn today. This is due in large part to advances in [[optometry]] which allow for better measurement of [[refraction error|refractive error]], so that [[glasses]] and [[contact lens]]es can be prescribed with different [[optical power|strengths]] in each eye.
The monocle did, however, gain a following in the stylish [[lesbian]] circles of the early 20th century, when lesbians would don a monocle for effect. Such women included [[Una Vincenzo, Lady Troubridge|Una Lady Troubridge]], [[Radclyffe Hall]], and Weimar German reporter [[Sylvia von Harden]]. (The painting ''Portrait of the Journalist Sylvia Von Harden'' by German expressionist painter [[Otto Dix]] depicts its subject sporting a monocle.)
Famous figures who wore a monocle include British politicians [[Joseph Chamberlain]], his son [[Austen Chamberlain|Austen]], [[Henry Chaplin]], and [[Angus Maude]]. [[Percy Toplis]] ([[The Monocled Mutineer]]), founder of Pakistan [[Mohammad Ali Jinnah]], Portuguese President [[António de Spínola]], filmmakers [[Fritz Lang]] and [[Erich von Stroheim]], prominent 19th-century Portuguese writer [[Eça de Queiroz]], Soviet writer [[Mikhail Bulgakov]], actor [[Conrad Veidt]], [[Dada]]ists [[Tristan Tzara]] and [[Raoul Hausmann]], esotericist [[Julius Evola]], French collaborationist politician [[Louis Darquier de Pellepoix]], [[Poet laureate]] [[Alfred Lord Tennyson]], singer [[Richard Tauber]], diplomat [[Christopher Ewart-Biggs]] (a smoked-glass monocle, to disguise his glass eye), Major [[Johnnie Cradock]], actors [[Ralph Lynn]], [[George Arliss]] and [[Martyn Green]], and [[Karl Marx]]. In another vein, [[G. E. M. Anscombe]] was one of only a few noted women who occasionally wore a monocle.<ref>{{cite news| url=https://www.theguardian.com/Archive/Article/0,4273,4115443,00.html | work=The Guardian | location=London | title=Elizabeth Anscombe | date=2001-01-11 | accessdate=2010-05-13 | first=Jane | last=O'Grady}}</ref> Famous wearers of the 21st century so far include [[astronomy|astronomer]] [[Patrick Moore|Sir Patrick Moore]], and former [[boxing|boxer]] [[Chris Eubank]]. Abstract expressionist painter [[Barnett Newman]] wore a monocle mainly for getting a closer look at artworks.<ref>Schneider, Pierre (Summer 1969). "Through the Louvre with Barnett Newman". ''Artnews''. '''68''' (4): 34–39, 70–72.</ref> [[Richard Tauber]] wore a monocle to mask a squint in one eye.
Fictional characters that wear monocles include Planters mascot [[Mr. Peanut]], aristocratic 1920s sleuth [[Lord Peter Wimsey]], the [[P. G. Wodehouse]] character [[Psmith]], [[Batman]] antagonist [[the Penguin]], and ''[[Avengers (comics)|Avengers]]'' antagonist and leader of HYDRA Baron Wolfgang Von Strucker. [[Count von Count]] from the children's program ''[[Sesame Street]]'' wears a monocle to show his distinction as a count. The ''[[The New Yorker|New Yorker]]'' mascot [[Eustace Tilley]], an early 19th-century dandy, is depicted using a monocle like a quizzing glass. A monocle is also a distinctive part of the costume of at least three [[Gilbert & Sullivan]] characters: [[The Pirates of Penzance#Roles|Major-General Stanley]] in ''[[The Pirates of Penzance]]'', Sir Joseph Porter in ''[[H.M.S. Pinafore]]'', and Reginald Bunthorne in ''[[Patience (opera)|Patience]]'', and composer Sullivan used one himself. In some variant productions, numerous other characters sport the distinctive eyewear, and some noted performers of the "G&S" repertoire also have worn a monocle. [[First Doctor|The Doctor]] as played by [[William Hartnell]] wore one. The French gentleman thief [[Arsene Lupin]] is commonly said to have a monocle, and is illustrated with it on whenever not under a disguise. [[Edgar Bergen]]'s famous dummy [[Charlie McCarthy]] wore a monocle and was normally attired in formal wear. [[Werner Klemperer]] as Kommandant Wilhelm Klink in ''[[Hogan's Heroes]]'' usually wore one in his left eye. [[Doc Savage]] aide 'Johnny' Littlejohn wore a monocle, as he was blind in one eye.

{{Infobox hospital | Name = Napa State Hospital | Org/Group = California Department of State Hospitals | Image = Napa State Hospital c. 1900.jpg | image alt = | image_size = 225 | Caption = Original [[Kirkbride Plan|Kirkbride]] building, {{circa}} 1900
(destroyed in 1906 earthquake) | map_type = | latitude = | longitude = | map_caption = | Logo = | Logo Size = | Location = [[Napa, California|Napa]], [[Napa Valley]] | Region = [[Napa County, California|Napa County]] | State = California | Country = U.S. | Coordinates = | Address = | HealthCare = | Funding = | Type = | Speciality = Psychiatry | Standards = | Emergency = | Helipad = | Affiliation = | Patron = | Network = | Beds = | Founded = 1875 | Closed = | Website = http://www.dsh.ca.gov/Napa/ | Wiki-Links = }} '''Napa State Hospital''' is a [[psychiatric hospital]] in [[Napa, California]], founded in 1875. It is located along [[California State Route 221]], also known as the Napa Vallejo Highway. One of California's five state hospitals, Napa State holds civil and forensic patients in a sprawling 138 acre campus. According to a hospital spokesperson, there were 2,338 people employed at the facility during the 2016-2017 fiscal year, making it one of the region's largest employers. The [[Napa Valley Cricket Club]] play their matches at McGrath Field, a multi-use sports field, at the eastern end of the Napa State Hospital campus. ==History== Originally named Napa Insane Asylum, the facility opened on November 15, 1875. It sat on {{convert|192|acre|km2|1}} of property stretching from the [[Napa River]] to what is now Skyline Park. The property was originally part of [[Rancho Tulucay]], part of a [[Ranchos of California|Mexican Land Grant]], sold by Cayetano Juarez to the [[State of California]] in 1872. The facility was originally built to relieve overcrowding at [[Stockton State Hospital|Stockton Asylum]]. By the early 1890s the facility had over 1,300 patients which was over double the original capacity it was designed to house. The original main building known as "The Castle" was an ornate and imposing building constructed with bricks. Facilities on the property included a large farm that included dairy and poultry ranches, vegetable garden and fruit orchards that provided a large part of the food supply consumed by the residents. It is also the site of [[The Cramps]] famous 1978 show when several patients attempted to escape. {{Cite journal | last = Kirkpatrick | first = Kirk | title = Once upon a time, a hospital castle was Napa Valley’s centerpiece | journal = [[Napa Valley Register]] | publisher = Lee Enterprises, Inc. | location = Napa, CA | date = February 20, 2018 | url = http://napavalleyregister.com/news/local/once-upon-a-time-a-hospital-castle-was-napa-valley/article_0de5d70f-895a-5a32-bc7a-255e8dbe3e2f.html#tracking-source=home-top-story | accessdate = February 21, 2018}} ==Notable patients== *[[California State University, Fullerton, massacre|Edward Charles Allaway]]{{cite news|url=http://www.latimes.com/local/lanow/la-me-ln-fullerton-killer-transfer-20160819-snap-story.html|title=Cal State Fullerton killer's hospital transfer sparks protests from his victims' families|work=Los Angeles Times|date=20 August 2016|author=Frank Shyong}} *[[2001 Nevada County shootings|Scott Harlan Thorpe]]{{Cite news|url=https://www.theunion.com/news/local-news/thorpe-pleads-guilty-to-murder/|title=Thorpe pleads guilty to murder|date=March 21, 2003|work=The Union|location=Nevada County, California}} ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== {{commonscat|Napa State Hospital}} *[http://www.dsh.ca.gov/Napa/ '''Napa State Hospital''' website] *[http://gis.oshpd.ca.gov/atlas/places/facility/106281266 This hospital in the CA Healthcare Atlas] — ''project by OSHPD''. *[http://www.doctorvista.com/dir/napa-state-hospital-2017396/profile Doctor Vista.com: Napa State Hospital profile] *[http://www.arcadiapublishing.com/9781467131995/Napa-State-Hospital Arcadiapublishing.com: ''Napa State Hospital''] - {{cleanup-reorganize|date=November 2014}} '''National Stroke Awareness Month''' is observed in the [[United States]] annually during the month of May. National Stroke Awareness Month was created to promote public awareness and reduce the incidence of [[stroke]] in the United States.
==History==
National Stroke Awareness Month began in May 1989 after President [[George H. W. Bush]] signed the Presidential Proclamation 5975.<ref>[http://www.presidency.ucsb.edu/ws/index.php?pid=20508#axzz1IIjVldn1 UCSB]</ref><ref>[http://zphib1920.org/zetashaveheart/may-national-stroke-awareness-month/ Zetas]</ref> National Stroke Awareness Month aims to increase the public awareness about the warning signs of stroke, symptoms of a stroke, stroke prevention, and the impact of stroke on survivors, families and caregivers. The United States Government, along with National Stroke Association, the American Heart Association, and other [[Nonprofit organization|non-profits]], work together to educate the American people about the prevention of stroke and provide key resources to stroke survivors.<ref>[http://www.presidency.ucsb.edu/ws/?pid=20508. UCSB]</ref>
==Symptoms== Because [[Tissue plasminogen activator|tPA]], a clot-busting drug, can only be administered to stroke patients within the first three hours of the onset of stroke, recognizing the symptoms of stroke is very important. National Stroke Awareness Month aims to educate Americans to recognize the symptoms of stroke.<ref>[http://www.ninds.nih.gov/disorders/stroke/preventing_stroke.htm Ninds]</ref><ref>[http://info.firstgiving.com/blog/bid/91765/May-is-National-Stroke-Awareness-Month First Giving]</ref>
==Prevention== 80 percent of strokes are caused by lifestyle; therefore, strokes are largely preventable.<ref>[https://www.blessinghospital.org/?id=952&sid=2 Blessing Hospital]</ref> Although some stroke [[risk factor]]s, such as age or race, cannot be controlled, there are many other steps individuals can take to reduce their risk of stroke.<ref>[http://www.stroke.org/we-can-help/survivors/stroke-recovery/first-steps-recovery/preventing-another-stroke National Stroke Association]</ref>

"'''Nothing About Us Without Us!'''" ([[Latin]]: "'''Nihil de nobis, sine nobis'''") is a [[slogan]] used to communicate the idea that no policy should be decided by any representative without the full and direct participation of members of the group(s) affected by that policy. This involves [[Nation state|national]], [[ethnic group|ethnic]], [[social model of disability|disability-based]], or other groups that are often thought to be [[social exclusion|marginalized]] from political, social, and economic opportunities.
The saying has its origins in [[Central Europe]]an political traditions. It was the political motto that helped establish—and, loosely translated into Latin, provided the name for—Poland's 1505 constitutional legislation, ''[[Nihil novi]]'', which first transferred governing authority from the monarch to the parliament. It subsequently became a byword for democratic norms. In this use, it is closely analogous to one of the most familiar slogans of the [[American Revolutionary War]], '[[No taxation without representation]]'.<ref>{{Cite book| last = Davies| first = Norman| title = Heart of Europe: The Past in Poland's Present| year = 1984|publisher = Oxford University Press}}</ref> It is also a long-standing principle of [[Hungary|Hungarian]] law and [[foreign policy]],<ref>{{Cite book| last = Bentley| first = R| title = Hungary, from 1848 to 1860| year = 1860| url = https://books.google.com/books?id=enuRlR0UHhoC&pg=PA173#v=onepage&q&f=false}}</ref> and was a cornerstone of the foreign policy of [[Second Polish Republic|interwar Poland]].<ref>{{Cite journal| volume = 16| issue = 48| pages = 558–571| last = Smogorzewski| first = Kazimierz| title = Poland's Foreign Relations| journal = The Slavonic and East European Review| year=1938| jstor = 4203420}}</ref><ref>{{Cite book| pages = 47–88| editors = P Wandycz (ed.)| last = Kornat| first = Marek|author2=J Micgiel | title = Reflections on Polish Foreign Policy| chapter = The Policy of Equilibrium and Polish Bilateralism| year = 2007| url = http://politologia.wsb-nlu.edu.pl/uploadedFiles/file/M_Kornat%20-%20The%20Policy%20of%20Equilibrium%20and%20Polish%20Bilateralism.pdf|isbn=0-9654520-7-7}}</ref>
The term in its English form came into use in [[disability activism]] during the 1990s. [[James Charlton (activist)|James Charlton]] relates that he first heard the term used in talks by [[South African]] disability activists Michael Masutha and William Rowland, who had in turn heard the phrase used by an unnamed [[East European]] activist at an earlier international disability rights conference. In 1998, Charlton used the saying as title for a book on disability rights.<ref>{{Cite book| publisher = University of California Press| isbn = 0-520-22481-7| last = Charlton| first = James I| title = Nothing About Us Without Us| accessdate = 2010-06-22| year = 1998| url = https://books.google.com/books?id=ohqff8DBt9gC&lpg=PA3&pg=PA3#v=onepage&q&f=false}}</ref> Disability rights activist [[David Werner]] used the same title for another book, also published in 1998.<ref>[http://www.dinf.ne.jp/doc/english/global/david/dwe001/dwe00101.htm ''Nothing About Us Without Us: Developing Innovative Technologies For, By and With Disabled Persons,'' Healthwrights, Palo Alto CA, 1998] {{ISBN|9780965558532}}</ref>
The saying has since moved from the [[disability rights]] movement to other [[interest group]], [[identity politics]], and [[populism|populist]] movements.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.aidsalliance.org/publicationsdetails.aspx?id=310|title=Nothing about us without us: Greater, meaningful involvement of people who use illegal drugs|accessdate=2010-08-02}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.sexworkawareness.org/nothing-about-us-without-us-the-shared-goals-of-the-harm-reduction-and-sex-worker-rights-movements|title=Nothing About Us Without Us: The Shared Goals of the Harm Reduction and Sex Worker Rights Movements|date=August 2, 2010}}</ref>

'''Patient safety''' is a discipline that emphasizes [[safety]] in [[health care]] through the prevention, reduction, reporting, and analysis of [[medical error]] that often leads to [[adverse effect]]s. The frequency and magnitude of avoidable adverse events experienced by [[patient]]s was not well known until the 1990s, when multiple countries reported staggering numbers of patients harmed and killed by medical errors. Recognizing that healthcare errors impact 1 in every 10 patients around the world, the [[World Health Organization]] calls patient safety an endemic concern.<ref>{{cite web |url= http://www.who.int/patientsafety/en/index.html | title= World Alliance for Patient Safety |accessdate=2008-09-27 |work= Organization Web Site | publisher= World Health Organization|date=}}</ref> Indeed, patient safety has emerged as a distinct healthcare discipline supported by an immature yet developing scientific framework. There is a significant transdisciplinary body of theoretical and research literature that informs the science of patient safety.<ref>{{cite journal | author = Patrick A. Palmieri| year = 2008 | title = The anatomy and physiology of error in averse healthcare events | journal =Advances in Health Care Management | volume = 7 | doi = 10.1016/S1474-8231(08)07003-1 | pages = 33–68|display-authors=etal}}</ref> The resulting patient safety knowledge continually informs improvement efforts such as: applying lessons learned from business and industry, adopting innovative technologies, educating providers and consumers, enhancing error reporting systems, and developing new economic incentives.[[File:Surgeon operating, Fitzsimons Army Medical Center, circa 1990.JPEG|250px|right|alt=A thoracic surgeon performs a mitral valve replacement at the Fitzsimons Army Medical Center.|A thoracic surgeon performs a mitral valve replacement at the [[Fitzsimons Army Medical Center]].]]
==Prevalence of adverse events== {{See also|Medical error}} [[File:Medicine aryballos Louvre CA1989-2183.jpg|thumb|Greek physician treating a patient, c. 480–470 BC (Louvre Museum, Paris, France)]] Millennia ago, Hippocrates recognized the potential for injuries that arise from the well-intentioned actions of healers. Greek healers in the 4th century BC drafted the [[Hippocratic Oath]] and pledged to "prescribe regimens for the good of my patients according to my ability and my judgment and never do harm to anyone."<ref>National Institute of Health, History of Medicine: [https://www.nlm.nih.gov/hmd/greek/greek_oath.html Greek Medicine]</ref> Since then, the directive ''primum non nocere'' (“first do no harm) has become a central tenet for contemporary medicine. However, despite an increasing emphasis on the [[Medicine#History|scientific basis of medical practice]] in Europe and the United States in the late 19th Century, data on adverse outcomes were hard to come by and the various studies commissioned collected mostly anecdotal events.<ref>The Anesthesia Patient Safety Foundation, [http://www.apsf.org/about/brief_history.mspx A Brief History] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20060113073054/http://www.apsf.org/about/brief_history.mspx |date=2006-01-13 }}</ref>
In the United States, the public and the medical specialty of [[anesthesia]] were shocked in April 1982 by the [[American Broadcasting Company|ABC]] television program [[20/20 (US television show)|20/20]] entitled ''The Deep Sleep''. Presenting accounts of anesthetic accidents, the producers stated that, every year, 6,000 Americans die or suffer brain damage related to these mishaps.<ref>Janice Tomlin (producer): ''The Deep Sleep: 6,000 will die or suffer brain damage'', WLS-TV Chicago, 20/20. April 22, 1982</ref> In 1983, the British [[Royal Society of Medicine]] and the [[Harvard Medical School]] jointly sponsored a symposium on anesthesia deaths and injuries, resulting in an agreement to share statistics and to conduct studies.<ref>Anesthesia Patient Safety Foundation: [http://www.apsf.org/about/rovenstine/part4.mspx The establishment of the APSF] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20060416075723/http://www.apsf.org/about/rovenstine/part4.mspx |date=2006-04-16 }} by Ellison C. Pierce, Jr., M.D.</ref> By 1984 the [[American Society of Anesthesiologists]] (ASA) had established the [[APSF|Anesthesia Patient Safety Foundation]] (APSF). The APSF marked the first use of the term "patient safety" in the name of professional reviewing organization.<ref>Anesthesia Patient Safety Foundation: [http://www.apsf.org/about_safety.php Comments From the Anesthesia Patient Safety Foundation]</ref> Although anesthesiologists comprise only about 5% of physicians in the United States, anesthesiology became the leading medical specialty addressing issues of patient safety.<ref>{{cite journal | author = David M Gaba | year = 2000 | title = Anesthesiology as a model for patient safety in health care | journal = Medical Care | volume = 320 | pages = 785–788 | url = http://bmj.bmjjournals.com/cgi/content/full/320/7237/785 | accessdate = 2006-06-24 | pmid = 10720368 | doi = 10.1136/bmj.320.7237.785 | issue = 7237 | pmc = 1117775 }}</ref> Likewise in Australia, the [[#Australian Patient Safety Foundation .28APSF.29|Australian Patient Safety Foundation]] was founded in 1989 for anesthesia error monitoring. Both organizations were soon expanded as the magnitude of the medical error crisis became known.
===''To Err is Human''=== [[File:Toerrishuman.gif|right]] In the United States, the full magnitude and impact of errors in health care was not appreciated until the 1990s, when several reports brought attention to this issue.<ref>{{cite journal | author = Thomas, Eric J. MD, MPH| year = 2000 | title = Incidence and Types of Adverse Events and Negligent Care in Utah and Colorado (Abstract) | journal = Medical Care | volume = 38 | pages = 261–271 | url = http://www.lww-medicalcare.com/pt/re/medcare/abstract.00005650-200003000-00003.htm;jsessionid=GcgGTLTnGGQWDtLjQpxzYKyyQCBnvq6r2lH3fTn5FVX0LGp0J696!-1734750035!-949856144!8091!-1 | accessdate = 2006-06-23 | doi = 10.1097/00005650-200003000-00003 | pmid=10718351|display-authors=etal}}</ref><ref name="pmid1987460">{{cite journal |vauthors=Brennan TA, Leape LL, Laird NM, etal |title=Incidence of adverse events and negligence in hospitalized patients. Results of the Harvard Medical Practice Study I |journal=N. Engl. J. Med. |volume=324 |issue=6 |pages=370–6 |year=1991 |pmid=1987460 |doi=10.1056/NEJM199102073240604|pmc=1743811 }}</ref> In 1999, the [[Institute of Medicine]] (IOM) of the National Academy of Sciences released a report, ''[[To Err is Human]]: Building a Safer Health System''.<ref name=IOM>{{Cite book | isbn = 978-0-309-06837-6 | editor-last = Kohn | editor-first = Linda T. | editor2-last = Corrigan | editor2-first = Janet M. | editor3-last = Donaldson | editor3-first = Molla S. | title = To Err is Human—Building a Safer Health System | publisher = [[National Academies Press]] | year = 2000 | location = Washington, D. C. | page = 312 | url = http://www.nap.edu/catalog.php?record_id=9728 }}</ref> The IOM called for a broad national effort to include establishment of a Center for Patient Safety, expanded reporting of adverse events, development of safety programs in health care organizations, and attention by regulators, health care purchasers, and professional societies. The majority of media attention, however, focused on the staggering statistics: from 44,000 to 98,000 preventable deaths annually due to medical error in hospitals, 7,000 preventable deaths related to medication errors alone. Within 2 weeks of the report's release, Congress began hearings and President Clinton ordered a government-wide study of the feasibility of implementing the report's recommendations.<ref>{{cite web | last=Charatan | first=Fred | year=2000 | url=http://bmj.bmjjournals.com/cgi/content/full/320/7235/597?ijkey=190e9b6dd6e8fec4ca3c2e353f290efb8237b334&keytype2=tf_ipsecsha | title=Clinton acts to reduce medical mistakes | publisher=BMJ Publishing Group | accessdate=2006-06-23}}</ref> Initial criticisms of the methodology in the IOM estimates<ref>{{cite journal | author1 = Harold C. Sox, Jr | author2 = Steven Woloshin | year = 2000 | title = How Many Deaths Are Due to Medical Error? Getting the Number Right | journal = Effective Clinical Practice | url = http://www.acponline.org/journals/ecp/novdec00/sox.htm | accessdate = 2006-06-22 | deadurl = yes | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20060206221458/http://www.acponline.org/journals/ecp/novdec00/sox.htm | archivedate = 2006-02-06 | df = }}</ref> focused on the statistical methods of amplifying low numbers of incidents in the pilot studies to the general population. However, subsequent reports emphasized the striking prevalence and consequences of medical error.
The experience has been similar in other countries.<ref>Commonwealth Fund International Survey: [http://www.cmwf.org/Publications/Publications_show.htm?doc_id=313012 Taking the Pulse of Health Care Systems: Experiences of Patients with Health Problems in Six Countries] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20060621014659/http://www.cmwf.org/Publications/Publications_show.htm?doc_id=313012 |date=2006-06-21 }} (2005)</ref> *Ten years after a groundbreaking Australian study revealed 18,000 annual deaths from medical errors,<ref>{{cite journal |vauthors=Wilson RM, Runciman WB, Gibberd RW, Harrison BT, Newby L, Hamilton JD |title=The Quality in Australian Health Care Study |journal=Med J Aust |volume=163 |issue=9 |pages=458–71 |date=November 1995 |pmid=7476634 }}</ref> Professor Bill Runciman, one of the study's authors and president of the [[#Australian Patient Safety Foundation .28APSF.29|Australian Patient Safety Foundation]] since its inception in 1989, reported himself a victim of a medical dosing error.<ref>Australian Broadcasting Corporation, ''The World Today'': [http://www.abc.net.au/worldtoday/content/2005/s1363139.htm Concerns over medication errors in Australian hospitals]</ref> *The Department of Health Expert Group in June 2000 estimated that over 850,000 incidents harm [[National Health Service]] hospital patients in the [[United Kingdom]] each year. ==Communication== Effective communication is essential for ensuring patient safety. Communicating starts with the provisioning of available information on any operational site especially in mobile professional services. Communicating continues with the reduction of administrative burden, releasing the operating staff and easing the operational demand by model driven orders, thus enabling adherence to a well executable procedure finalised with a qualified minimum of required feedback.
===Effective and ineffective communication=== [[File:Nurse takes a patient's blood pressure.jpg|thumb|Nurse and patient non-verbal communication|right]]
The use of effective communication among patients and healthcare professionals is critical for achieving a patient's optimal health outcome. However, according to the [[Patient safety organization#Canadian Patient Safety Institute|Canadian Patient Safety Institute]], ineffective communication has the opposite effect as it can lead to patient harm.<ref name=CPSI>{{cite web | url=http://www.patientsafetyinstitute.ca/English/toolsResources/safetyCompetencies/Documents/Safety%20Competencies.pdf | title=The Safety Competencies - Enhancing Patient Safety Across the Health Professions | edition=first | date=August 2009 | publisher=Canadian Patient Safety Institute | vauthors=Frank JR, Brien S | isbn=978-1-926541-15-0 | access-date=2014-11-04 | archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130614151111/http://www.patientsafetyinstitute.ca/English/toolsResources/safetyCompetencies/Documents/Safety%20Competencies.pdf | archive-date=2013-06-14 | dead-url=yes | df= }}</ref> Communication with regards to patient safety can be classified into two categories: prevention of adverse events and responding to adverse events. Use of effective communication can aid in the prevention of adverse events, whereas ineffective communication can contribute to these incidences. If ineffective communication contributes to an adverse event, then better and more effective communication skills must be applied in response to achieve optimal outcomes for the patient's safety. There are different modes in which healthcare professionals can work to optimize the safety of patients which include both verbal and nonverbal communication, as well as the effective use of appropriate communication technologies.<ref name=CPSI/>
Methods of effective verbal and nonverbal communication include treating patients with respect and showing empathy, clearly communicating with patients in a way that best fits their needs, practicing active listening skills, being sensitive with regards to cultural diversity and respecting the privacy and confidentiality rights of the patient.<ref name=CPSI/> To use appropriate communication technology, healthcare professionals must choose which channel of communication is best suited to benefit the patient. Some channels are more likely to result in communication errors than others, such as communicating through telephone or email (missing nonverbal messages which are an important element of understanding the situation). It is also the responsibility of the provider to know the advantages and limitations of using [[electronic health records]], as they do not convey all information necessary to understanding patient needs. If a health care professional is not practicing these skills, they are not being an effective communicator which may affect patient outcome.<ref name=CPSI/>
The goal of a healthcare professional is to aid a patient in achieving their optimal health outcome, which entails that the patient's safety is not at risk. Practice of effective communication plays a large role in promoting and protecting patient safety.<ref name=CPSI/>
===Teamwork and communication===
During complex situations, communication between health professionals must be at its best. There are several techniques, tools, and strategies used to improve communication. Any team should have a clear purpose and each member should be aware of their role and be involved accordingly.<ref name=CPSI/> To increase the quality of communication between people involved, regular feedback should be provided. Strategies such as briefings allow the team to be set on their purpose and ensure that members not only share the goal but also the process they will follow to achieve it.<ref name=CPSI/> Briefings reduce interruptions, prevent delays and build stronger relationships, resulting in a strong patient safety environment.<ref name=CPSI/>
[[Debriefing]] is another useful strategy. Healthcare providers meet to discuss a situation, record what they learned and discuss how it might be better handled. [[Closed loop communication]] is another important technique used to ensure that the message that was sent is received and interpreted by the receiver. [[SBAR]] is a structured system designed to help team members communicate about the patient in the most convenient form possible.<ref name=CPSI/> Communication between healthcare professionals not only helps achieve the best results for the patient but also prevents any unseen incidents.<ref name=CPSI/>
===Safety culture=== {{see also|Safety culture}} As is the case in other industries, when there is a mistake or error made people look for someone to blame. This may seem natural, but it creates a blame culture where ''who'' is more important than ''why'' or ''how''. A ''just culture'', also sometimes known as ''no blame'' or ''no fault'', seeks to understand the root causes of an incident rather than just who was involved.<ref>{{cite web|author1=David Marx|title=Patient Safety and the "Just Culture:" A Primer For Health Care Executives|url=http://www.safer.healthcare.ucla.edu/safer/archive/ahrq/FinalPrimerDoc.pdf|website=University of California Los Angeles|accessdate=30 October 2014|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160303232047/http://www.safer.healthcare.ucla.edu/safer/archive/ahrq/FinalPrimerDoc.pdf|archive-date=2016-03-03|dead-url=yes|df=}}</ref>
In health care, there is a move towards a patient safety culture.<ref>{{cite web|title=Canadian Disclosure Guidelines BEING OPEN WITH PATIENTS AND FAMILIES|url=http://www.patientsafetyinstitute.ca/English/toolsResources/disclosure/Documents/CPSI%20Canadian%20Disclosure%20Guidelines.pdf|website=Patient Safety Institute|accessdate=30 October 2014|page=16|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150122052204/http://www.patientsafetyinstitute.ca/English/toolsResources/disclosure/Documents/CPSI%20Canadian%20Disclosure%20Guidelines.pdf|archive-date=2015-01-22|dead-url=yes|df=}}</ref> This applies the lessons learned from other industries, such as [[Aviation safety|aviation]], [[Maritime Resource Management|marine]], and [[Occupational safety and health|industrial]], to a health care setting.
When assessing and analyzing an incident, individuals involved are much more likely to be forthcoming with their own mistakes if they know that their job is not at risk.<ref>{{cite book|last1=Wolf|first1=Zane Robinson|last2=Hughes|first2=Ronda G.|title=Patient Safety and Quality: An Evidence-Based Handbook for Nurses.|publisher=Agency for Healthcare Research and Quality|location=Chapter 35|accessdate=}}</ref> This allows a much more complete and clear picture to be formed of the facts of an event. From there, [[root cause analysis]] can occur. There are often multiple causative factors involved in an adverse or near miss event.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Kunadharaju|first1=Kumar|last2=Smith|first2=Todd|last3=DeJoy|first3=David|title=Line-of-duty deaths among U.S. firefighters: An analysis of fatality investigations|journal=Accident Analysis & Prevention|date=May 2011|volume=43|issue=3|pages=1171–1180|url=http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0001457510004070|accessdate=6 November 2014|doi=10.1016/j.aap.2010.12.030}}</ref> It is only after all contributing factors have been identified that effective changes can be made that will prevent a similar incident from occurring.
===Disclosure of an incident===
After an adverse event occurs, each country has its own way of dealing with the incident. In Canada, a quality improvement review is primarily used. A quality improvement review is an evaluation that is completed after an adverse event occurs with the intention to both fix the problem, as well as preventing it from happening again.<ref>https://www.cms.gov/Regulations-and-Guidance/Guidance/Manuals/downloads/qio110c16.pdf</ref> The individual provinces and territories have laws on whether it is required to disclose the quality improvement review to the patient. Healthcare providers have an obligation to disclose any adverse event to their patients because of ethical and professional guidelines.<ref name="royalcollege.ca">http://www.royalcollege.ca/portal/page/portal/rc/common/documents/policy/getting_it_right_e.pdf</ref> If more providers participate in the quality improvement review, it can increase interdisciplinary collaboration and can sustain relationships between departments and staff.<ref name="royalcollege.ca"/> In the US, [[clinical peer review]] is used: uninvolved medical staff review the event and work toward preventing further incidents.
The disclosure of adverse events is important in maintaining trust in the relationship between healthcare provider and patient. It is also important in learning how to avoid these mistakes in the future by conducting quality improvement reviews, or clinical peer review. If the provider accurately handles the event, and disclose it to the patient and their family, he/she can avoid getting punished, which includes lawsuits, fines and suspension.<ref>http://intqhc.oxfordjournals.org/content/intqhc/early/2010/08/13/intqhc.mzq042.full.pdf</ref>
